column2: PARAMETERS
column3: Symbol parameters description in expression view & customizer GUI

column2: The expression defining whether or not the ADC functionality should be present in the component. For CapSense component, it is always false. For ADC component, it is always true. For CapSense_ADC component, it is true if the total count of required ADC channels (AdcTotalChannels parameter) is greater than 0, and false otherwise.

Enable the ADC channel that does not require a dedicated port pin input.
When disabled, all ADC input channels have port pins assigned.
When enabled, the ADC channel selected by the AdcSelectAmuxBusChannel parameter does not use a dedicated pin for input, instead it takes an input from AMUXBUS-B.
Enables the auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine initialization in ADC conversion.

Sets an auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine initialization in ADC converson (in cycles).
Applicable only if AdcAzEnable parameter is enabled. The range of valid values is 1-255.

Contains a comma-separated list of pin aliases for ADC input channels.
Used by the AdcInput pins on the component schematic.
ADC resolution selection.
Selects the ADC channel that does not require a dedicated port pin input. The range of valid values is from 0 to $AdcTotalChannels-1.

The total input channels to ADC. The range of valid values is from 1 (ADC_CSD component) or 0 (CapSense_ADC component) to 10. The ADC functionality of CapSense_ADC component is disabled when a parameter value is set to 0.
The expression providing the total count of dedicated ADC channels. When AdcAmuxbInputEnable is set to false, the parameter value equals AdcTotalChannels, otherwise, it is decremented by one.

The reference voltage used for ADC operation, in Volts.
The range of valid values is from 1.2V to VDDA - 0.6V, where VDDA is the input voltage of VDDA pin as set in the Design-Wide Resources (*.cydwr) System editor.
When set to -1 (default), the reference voltage (VREF) depends on VDDA:
VDDA < 2.733V: VREF = 1.2V
2.733V <= VDDA < 4.5V: VREF = 2.133V
VDDA >= 4.5V: VREF = 3.84V
The macro generated by the API customizer reflects VREFGEN gain register value.

Selects the type of baseline needed for design.
IIR (default) - Selects the IIR filter based baseline algorithm.
CY (Bucket) Baseline - Selects Cypress' "bucket" method for the baseline algorithm.

Enable the turning-off block after a scan to save additional power.
Disabled (default) - The CSD block will be always turned ON.
 This allows the other components (IDAC) work along with CapSense component in a project.
Enabled - The CSD block will be turned ON only during a scan.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD block 0.
Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD block 0.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Contains a comma-separated list of the electrode aliases for CSD widgets on CSD block 0.
Used by the Sns/Sns0 pins on the component schematic.

Contains the total count of the CSD electrodes on CSD block 0.
Used by the Sns/Sns0 pins on the component schematic.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield electrode signal for phase alignment.
Most designs work with the No Delay option, and it is the recommended value.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield electrode signal for phase alignment.
Most designs work with the No Delay option, and it is the recommended value.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield electrode is used to reduce the sensor parasitic capacitance, enable water-tolerant
 CapSense designs, and enhance the detection range for Proximity sensors.
When the shield electrode is disabled, all configurable parameters associated with the shield electrode are hidden.
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the initialization source for the shield tank electrode, when the shield tank (Csh) capacitor is enabled.
Two options are available:
- Vref - precharge the shield tank by connecting Vref to the Csh capacitor.
- IO Buffer - precharge shield tank by connecting the VDD supply to the Csh capacitor and turning it off
 using feedback system when the Csh voltage reaches Vref.
This option is available only when the Csh capacitor is assigned to one of the dedicated Csh pins
 (refer to device datasheet for pin details) and these dedicated pins are available for Csh
 when the CSX sensing method is not used in the project.
The recommended source of precharge is IO buffer.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield tank capacitor is used to increase the drive capacity of the shield electrode driver and recommended for enabling when the shield electrode capacitance is higher than 100 pF.
The recommended value for a shield tank capacitor is 10 nF/5v/X7R or an NPO capacitor.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Select the number of shield electrodes required in the design. 
Most designs work with one dedicated shield electrode; however, some designs require multiple dedicated shield electrodes to ease the PCB layout routing or to minimize the PCB real-estate used for the shield layer.
The minimum value is 0 (i.e. shield signal could be routed to sensors using Inactive sensor connection parameter) and the maximum value is equal to the total number of CapSense-enabled port pins available for the selected device.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD block 1.
Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.
Applicable only if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD block 1.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.
Applicable only if CSD2x is enabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of electrode aliases for the CSD widgets on CSD block 1.
Used by the Sns1 pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSD2x is enabled.

Contains the total count of the CSD electrodes on CSD block 1.
Used by the Sns1 pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSD2x is enabled.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield electrode signal for phase alignment.
Most designs work with the No Delay option, and it is the recommended value.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield electrode signal for the phase alignment.
Most designs work with the No Delay option, and it is the recommended value.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield electrode is used to reduce the sensor parasitic capacitance, enable water-tolerant CapSense designs and enhance the detection range for Proximity sensors.
Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the initialization source for the shield tank electrode, when the shield tank (Csh) capacitor is enabled.
Two options are available:
- Vref - precharge the shield tank by connecting Vref to the Csh capacitor.
- IO Buffer - precharge the shield tank by connecting the VDD supply to the Csh capacitor and turning it off using the feedback system when the Csh voltage reaches Vref.
This option is available only when the Csh capacitor is assigned to one of the dedicated Csh pins
 (refer to device datasheet for pin details) and these dedicated pins are available for Csh
 when the CSX sensing method is not used in the project.
The recommended source of precharge is IO buffer.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield tank capacitor is used to increase the drive capacity of the shield electrode driver and is recommended to enable when the shield electrode capacitance is higher than 100pF.
The recommended value for a shield tank capacitor is 10 nF/5v/X7R or an NPO capacitor.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the number of shield electrodes required in the design. 
Most designs work with one dedicated shield electrode; however, some designs require multiple dedicated shield electrodes to ease the PCB layout routing or to minimize the PCB real-estate used for the shield layer.
The minimum value is 0 (i.e. shield signal could be routed to sensors using Inactive sensor connection parameter) and the maximum value is equal to the total number of CapSense-enabled port pins available for the selected device.
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled.
Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Enabling this parameter allows two sensors to be scanned in two, simultaneously used, CSD hardware blocks.
This option is available only on devices supporting two CSD blocks.

Enables auto-zero prior to fine initialization for the CSD sensing method.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Sets an auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine initialization for the CSD sensing method.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.
Applicable only when CsdAutoZeroEnable is enabled.

When selected, all CSD widgets share the same sense clock with the frequency specified in
 the Sense clock frequency (kHz) parameter.
Otherwise, a sense clock frequency can be entered
 separately for each CSD widget in the Widget Details tab.

Selects the compensation IDAC implementation method when using CSDv2.
Enabled (default) - Use IDACB as the compensation IDAC
Disabled - Use LEG2 of IDACA as compensation IDAC
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.
Represents the percentage of contribution by the compensation IDAC when using the Dual IDAC sensing.
The internal parameter automatically enabled by the customizer when at least one widget uses the CSD sensing mode AND the dual-channel CSD (CSD2x) is not selected.

When enabled, the values of IDACs of CSD widgets are automatically set by the component.
It is recommended to select Enable IDAC auto-calibration for robust operation.
SmartSense Auto-tuning can be enabled only when Enable IDAC auto-calibration is selected.

The compensation IDAC is used to compensate for the sensor parasitic capacitance to improve the performance.
Enabling the compensation IDAC is recommended unless one IDAC is required for other purpose use in the project.

Selects the sensing Config needed in CSD mode.
IDAC Sourcing (default) - Select IDAC sourcing sensing configuration (-ve charge transfer)
IDAC Sinking - Select the IDAC sinking sensing configuration (+ve charge transfer).

Selects the state of the sensor when not being scanned.  
- Ground (default) - All inactive sensors are connected to Ground.
- High-Z - All inactive sensors are floating (not connected to GND or Shield).
- Shield - All inactive sensors are connected to Shield.
The Shield option is available only if an Enable shield electrode check-box is set.
Ground is the recommended option for this parameter when the water tolerance is not required for the design.
Selects Shield when the design needs water tolerance or sensor parasitic capacitance reduction in a design.

Selects resistance of the switches used for Cmod and Csh_Tank initialization.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Selects the modulator clock frequency used for the CSD sensing method.
Enters any value between the min and max limits, based on the availability of the clock divider.
The higher modulator clock frequency reduces sensor scan time.
Therefore, results in lower power and reduces the noise in the raw counts,
 so recommended to use the highest possible frequency.

Enables noise metric evaluation for CSD scan.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Sets the max allowed bad conversions in a sample.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.
Applicable only if CsdNoiseMetricEnable is enabled.
Represents the settling time delay (in uS) prior to scan is started.
Represents the rawcount calibration level (percentage) to be used when auto-calibration of CSD widgets is enabled.

Sets the CSD sense clock frequency.
When SmartSense is selected in the CSD tuning mode, sense clock frequency is automatically
 set by the component to the optimal value.
When the Enable common sense clock is unselected, a sense clock frequency can be set
 individually for each widget in the Widget Details tab.

The sense clock is used to sample the input sensor.
The Spread Spectrum Clock (SSC) provides a dithering clock source with a center frequency equal to the frequency set in the sense clock frequency parameter.
The PRS clock source spreads the clock using pseudo-random sequencer.
Direct source disables both SSC and PRS sources and uses a fixed-frequency clock.
Selects the resistance of switches used to drive the shield electrode when an internal shield drive is used.
Represents a series resistance value to be considered  while decising on the widget/sensor clock value when auto-tuning is enabled.

Select the tuning mode for CSD widgets. Three options are available:
SmartSense (Full Auto-Tune) - This is the quickest way to tune a design. Mostly all widget parameters are automatically tuned by the component.
SmartSense (Hardware parameters only) - Hardware parameters are automatically set by the component, all threshold parameters can be manually set by the user
Manual - SmartSense auto-tuning is disabled, all widget parameters must be manually tuned.
This setting is applicable only to CSD widgets (CSX widgets always use Manual tuning).

The reference voltage used for CSDv2 operation, in Volts. The range of valid values is from 1.2V to VDDA - 0.6V, where VDDA is the input voltage of the VDDA pin as set in the Design-Wide Resources (*.cydwr) System editor.
When set to -1 (default), the reference voltage value (VREF) depends on VDDA:
VDDA < 2.6V: VREF = 1.2V
2.6V <= VDDA < 3.2V: VREF = 1.4769V
3.2V <= VDDA < 4.7V: VREF = 2.0211V
VDDA >= 4.7V: VREF = 2.7429V
The macro generated by the API customizer reflects the VREFGEN gain register value.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD block 0.
Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD block 0.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Rx sensor aliases for CSX sensors on CSD block 0.
Used by the Rx0 pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes on CSD block 0.
Used by the Rx0 pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD block 1.
Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.
Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD block 1.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.
Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Rx electrode aliases for the CSX sensors on CSD block 1.
Used by the Rx1 pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes on CSD block 1.
Used by the Rx1 pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.
Indicates whether the two-channel operation of CSX widgets (CSX2x) is enabled.
Enables auto-zero prior to fine initialization for the CSX sensing method.
Sets an auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine initialization in the CSX sensing method.

When selected, all CSX widgets share the same Tx clock with the frequency specified in the
 Tx clock frequency (kHz) parameter.
Otherwise, a Tx clock frequency can be entered separately
 for each CSX widget in the Widget Details tab.
The internal parameter automatically enabled by the customizer when at least one widget uses the CSX sensing mode AND dual-channel CSX (CSX2x) is not selected.

When enabled, IDACs values for the CSX widgets are automatically set by the component.
It is recommended to select Enable IDAC auto-calibration for robust operation.

Controls how many of the IDAC bits should be considered for auto-calibration of the CSX widgets.
Less bits leads to faster calibration time.
Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.

Controls how many of the IDAC bits should be considered for auto-calibration of the CSX widgets.
Less bits leads to faster calibration time.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.
Selects the resistance of switches used for Cint1 and Cint2 initialization.
Indicates the maximum number of reported fingers. If the number of fingers on the touchpad exceeds this number, no finger will be reported.
The maximum possible number of local maxima for CSX touchpad.

Selects the modulator clock frequency used for the CSX sensing method.
Enter any value between the min and max limits based on the availability of the clock divider.
Enable/disable the multi-phase scan for CSX.
Enables the noise metric evaluation for the CSX scan.

Sets max allowed bad conversions in a sample.
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.
Applicable only if CsxNoiseMetricEnable is enabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Multiphase Tx electrode aliases for the CSX sensors.
Used by the Mptx/Mptx2x pins on the component schematic.
Applicable only if Multiphase Tx is enabled for at least one widget.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Rx electrode aliases for the CSX widgets.
Used by the Rx pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSX2x is disabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Tx electrode aliases for the CSX widgets.
Used by the Tx/Tx2x pins on the component schematic.

Contains the total count of the Multiphase Tx electrodes for the CSX widgets.
Used by the Mptx/Mptx2x pins on the component schematic.
Applicable only if the Multiphase Tx is enabled for at least one widget.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes for the CSX widgets.
Used by the Rx pin on the component schematic.
Applicable only if CSX2x is disabled.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes for the CSX widgets.
Used by the Tx/Tx2x pin on the component schematic.
Represents the rawcount calibration level (percentage) to be used when auto-calibration of the CSX widgets is enabled.
Enable/Disable over sampling and scan skip on specific nodes.

Sets the CSX Tx clock frequency.
The highest Tx clock frequency producing the maximum signal and is the recommended setting.
When the Enable common Tx clock is unselected, a Tx Clock frequency can be set individually
 for each widget in the Widget Details tab.

A Tx clock is used to sample the input sensor.
The Spread Spectrum Clock (SSC) provides a dithering clock source with the center frequency equal to the frequency
set in the Tx Clock frequency parameter.
Direct source disables the SSC source and uses a fixed-frequency clock.
Auto is the recommended clock source selection.

The internal parameter enabling generation of a special set of component APIs to be processed by the Doxygen tool.
The configuration consistency is not guaranteed, cannot be used on the real designs.
Internal read-only parameter set to true on ADC and CapSense_ADC component catalog placements.
The internal read-only parameter set to true on CapSense and CapSense_ADC component catalog placements.
Represents a low baseline reset size for sensors.
Indicates whether multi-frequency scanning is enabled.

Selects a number of centroid supported on sliders. The available options are 1, 2 or 3. The default is 1 (Legacy).
Applicable only to Radial and Linear slider widgets. Not supported on diplexed sliders.
Indicates whether the debounce for ON to OFF transition is enabled.
The centroid Position IIR filter coefficient for sliders and touchpads. The range of valid values is 1-255.

The finite impulse response filter (no feedback) with equally weighted coefficients.
It takes four of most recent samples and computes their average.
Eliminates the periodic noise (e.g. noise from AC remains).
Applicable only to proximity widgets.

The raw count averege filter sample size selection.
Applicable only to proximity widgets when the average filter is enabled.

Enables the custom filter.
Applicable only to proximity widgets.

Baseline IIR filter coefficient selection for sensors in proximity widgets.
The range of valid values is 1-255.
Applicable only to proximity widgets.

Enables the infinite-impulse response filter with a step response similar to an RC low-pass filter
thereby passing the low frequency signals (finger touch responses).
Applicable only to proximity widgets.

the coefficient (N) of an IIR filter for raw counts. 
The range of valid values is 1-128.
Applicable only to proximity widgets when the IIR filter is enabled.
Applicable only to proximity widgets when IIR filter is enabled.

Enables a non-linear filter that takes three of most recent samples and computes the median value.
This filter eliminates spikes noise typically caused by motors and switching power supplies.
Applicable only to proximity widgets.

The finite-impulse response filter (no feedback) with equally weighted coefficients.
It takes four of most recent samples and computes their average.
Eliminates the periodic noise (e.g. noise from AC remains).
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets.

The raw count average filter sample size selection.
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets when the average filter is enabled.

Enables the custom filter.
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets.

Baseline IIR filter coefficient selection for sensors in non-proximity widgets.
The range of valid values is 1-255.

Enables the infinite-impulse response filter with a step response similar to an RC low-pass filter
thereby passing low frequency signals (finger touch responses).
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets.

The IIR filter coefficient (N) for raw counts. 
The range of valid values in 1-128.
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets when the IIR filter is enabled.

Enables a non-linear filter that takes three of most recent samples and computes the median value.
This filter eliminates spikes noise typically caused by motors and switching power supplies.
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets.

The BIST/Class-B library supports the following: the sensor short test, test baseline and raw count limits, CRC for widget-specific register map data, measuring an external cap (Cmod, Csh_tank, CintA and CintB) value and test baseline data consistency.
Additionally, measuring of VDDA and two internal reference caps are supported for CSDv2.

When enabled, the baseline is always updated and when disabled, the baseline is updated only when the difference between the baseline and raw count is less than the noise threshold.
The sensor auto-reset prevents the sensor from permanently turning on when the raw count
 accidentally rises because of a large power-supply voltage fluctuation or due to other spurious conditions.
Selection of the sensor auto-reset implementation method.
The number of samples required before a baseline is reset, when the sensor auto-reset is enabled.

Selects a data size for widgets in the component.
This applies to Finger Threshold (all widgets) and Proximity Touch Threshold (proximity widgets).
In SmartSense (Full Auto-tune) mode, parameter value is ignored and threshold register size is always 16-bit.
The expression provided by the customizer to obtain a VDDA value as set in the System DWR.
Contains the widget/sensor configuration.
PROPERTIES
Finger capacitance for the widget, in pF.
Enables usage of specific duplexing sensor pattern to double the slider physical touch sensing area.
Sets the maximum Centroid position for the slider.
Sets the maximum column (X-axis) Centroid position fo a touchpad.
Sets the maximum row (Y-axis) Centroid position for touchpad.
Enables the specific filter on a Centroid position value reducing noise due to a varying finger touch.
Enables Multiphase Tx scan of the CSX widget.
Sets the sense clock frequency for the CSD widget.
Displays the actual sense clock frequency (as obtained with the closest valid sense clock divider).
Sets the row sense clock frequency for the CSD matrix buttons and Touchpad widgets.
Displays the actual row sense clock frequency (as obtained with the closest valid row sense clock divider).
Sets the Tx clock frequency for the CSX widget.
Displays the actual Tx clock frequency (as obtained with the closest valid Tx clock divider).
Selects the scan resolution of CSD widgets (resolution of capacitance-to-digital conversion).
Selects the number of sub-conversions for CSX widgets.
Sets the modulator IDAC value for the CSD widget.s
Sets a modulator IDAC value for the row sensors of the CSD Matrix Buttons and Touchpad widgets.
Sets the touch level to determine the sensor state based on the signal.
Sets the touch level to detect a finger touch on the proximity sensor.
Sets the raw count limit below which is considered as noise.
Sets the raw count limit below which the baseline is not updated for the number of samples specified by the Low baseline reset parameter.
Sets the number of abnormally low raw counts required to reset the baseline.
A parameter used to prevent the sensor status output from random toggling due to system noise, used in conjunction with the Finger Threshold to determine the sensor state
Sets the number of consecutive CapSense scans during which a sensor must be active to generate an ON state.

The square of the "speed" (maximum distance change per refresh interval) threshold distinguishing a fast finger movement from separate finger touches (in [pixels/refresh interval]).
Squared speeds exceeding this value indicate separate finger touches.
Squared speeds below this value indicate fast single finger movement.
Sets the Compensation IDAC value for the specific CSD sensor.
Sets an IDAC value for each CSX sensor/node.

Selects a port pin for the sensor (CSD sensing) and electrode (CSX sensing). The available options are to use a dedicated pin for a sensor or reuse one or more pins from any other sensors in the component. Reusing the pins of any other sensors from any widgets helps to create a ganged sensor.
IDAC value of the sensor
This parameter defines the maximum X-Axis displacement acceptable for valid one finger click gestures on touchpad.
This parameter defines the maximum Y-Axis displacement acceptable for valid one finger click gestures on touchpad.
This parameter defines the maximum displacement acceptable for valid one finger click gestures for sliders.
Duration of the one finger touch should remain above the limit specifed by this parameter for a single click to be valid.
Duration of the one finger touch should remain belown the limit specifed by this parameter for a single click to be valid.
This parameter defines the maximum position radius displacement (center being position of first touch) that the second click in a one finger double click sequence can extend on touchpad.
This parameter defines the maximum position displacement (from position of first touch) that the second click in a one finger double click sequence can extend on sliders.
The time interval between the first and second clicks should remain above the limit specifed by this parameter for a one finger double click to be valid.
The time interval between the first and second clicks should remain below the limit specifed by this parameter for a one finger double click to be valid.
This parameter defines the maximum X-Axis displacement acceptable for valid two finger click gestures on touchpad.
This parameter defines the maximum Y-Axis displacement acceptable for valid two finger click gestures on touchpad.
This parameter defines the maximum position displacement acceptable for valid two finger click gestures on sliders.
Duration of the two finger touch should remain above the limit specifed by this parameter for a two finger single click to be valid.
Duration of the two finger touch should remain below the limit specifed by this parameter for a two finger single click to be valid.
This parameter defines the maximum position radius (center being position of first touch) that the second click in a two finger double click sequence can extend on touchpad.
This parameter defines the maximum position displacement (from position of first touch) that the second click in a two finger double click sequence can extend on sliders.
The time difference between the first and second clicks should remain above the limit specifed by this parameter for a two two finger double click to be valid.
The time difference between the first and second clicks should remain below the limit specifed by this parameter for a two two finger double click to be valid.

This parameter defines the minimum number of similar ST scrolls that should be performed for a finger motion to be considered as valid ST scroll. A touch has to move, at a minimum (Debounce + 1) times in the same direction to be considered as a scroll in that direction.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on X-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans for ST scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step1.
This is minimum displacement needs to be detected on Y-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans for ST scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step1.
This is minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider between two concecutive scans for ST scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step1.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is falls between X-Axis Position Threshold1 and X-Axis Position Threshold2. 2. Y-Axis displacement is falls between Y-Axis Position Threshold1 and Y-Axis Position Threshold2. For slider: 3. Position displacement is falls between  Position Threshold1 and Position Threshold2.
If displacement detected on X-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds,  "scroll step2" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on Y-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter,  "scroll step2" shall be reported.
This is minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider between two concecutive scans for ST scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step2.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is falls between X-Axis Position Threshold2 and X-Axis Position Threshold3.  2. Y-Axis displacement is falls between Y-Axis Position Threshold2 and Y-Axis Position Threshold3. For slider: 3. Position displacement is falls between  Position Threshold2 and Position Threshold3.
If displacement detected on X-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds,  "scroll Step3" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on Y-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter,  "scroll Step3" shall be reported.
This is minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider between two concecutive scans for ST scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step3.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is falls between X-Axis Position Threshold3 and X-Axis Position Threshold4.  2. Y-Axis displacement is falls between Y-Axis Position Threshold3 and Y-Axis Position Threshold4. For slider: 3. Position displacement is falls between  Position Threshold3 and Position Threshold4.
If displacement detected on X-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds the value defined by this parameter,  "scroll Step4" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on Y-axis of a touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter,  "scroll Step4" shall be reported.
This is minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider between two concecutive scans for ST scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step4.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is greater than X-Axis Position Threshold4. 2. Y-Axis displacement is greater thanY-Axis Position Threshold4. For slider: 3. Position displacement is greater than Position Threshold4.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on X-axis of touchpad for an ST scroll gresture followed by a left off event to be considered as valid insertial scroll.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on Y-axis of touchpad for an ST scroll gresture followed by a left off event to be considered as valid insertial scroll.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider for an ST scroll gresture followed by a left off event to be considered as valid insertial scroll.

Selects inertial scroll delay rate: Low - Uses 32-byte array for inertial scroll implementation, reports few intertial scrolls. High - Uses 64-byte array for inertial scroll implementation and reports more intertial scrolls.

This parameter defines the minimum number of similar DT scrolls that should be performed for a finger motion to be considered as valid DT scroll. A touch has to move, at a minimum (Debounce + 1) times in the same direction to be considered as a scroll in that direction.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on X-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans for DT scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step1.
This is minimum displacement needs to be detected on Y-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans for DT scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step1.
This is minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider between two concecutive scans for DT scroll to be valid. The reported scroll shall be scroll step1.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is falls between X-Axis Position Threshold1 and X-Axis Position Threshold2.  2. Y-Axis displacement is falls between Y-Axis Position Threshold1 and Y-Axis Position Threshold2. For slider: 3. Position displacement is falls between  Position Threshold1 and Position Threshold2.
If displacement detected on X-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds, "scroll step2" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on Y-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter, "scroll step2" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on slider between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter, "scroll step2" shall be reported.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is falls between X-Axis Position Threshold2 and X-Axis Position Threshold3.  2. Y-Axis displacement is falls between Y-Axis Position Threshold2 and Y-Axis Position Threshold3.  For slider: 3. Position displacement is falls between  Position Threshold2 and Position Threshold3.
If displacement detected on X-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds, "scroll step2" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on Y-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter, "scroll Step3" shall be reported.
If displacement detected onslider between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter, "scroll Step3" shall be reported.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is falls between X-Axis Position Threshold3 and X-Axis Position Threshold4.  2. Y-Axis displacement is falls between Y-Axis Position Threshold3 and Y-Axis Position Threshold4. For slider: 3. Position displacement is falls between  Position Threshold3 and Position Threshold4.
If displacement detected on X-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds the value defined by this parameter, "scroll Step4" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on Y-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter, "scroll Step4" shall be reported.
If displacement detected on slider between two concecutive scans exceeds  the value defined by this parameter, "scroll Step4" shall be reported.

This parameter defines the number of scrolls that will be reported if finger position displacement between two concecutive scans meets one of the  rule below. For touchpad: 1. X-Axis displacement is greater than X-Axis Position Threshold4. 2. Y-Axis displacement is greater thanY-Axis Position Threshold4. For slider: 3. Position displacement is greater than Position Threshold4.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on X-axis of touchpad for an DT scroll gresture followed by a left off event to be considered as valid insertial scroll.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on Y-axis of touchpad for an DT scroll gresture followed by a left off event to be considered as valid insertial scroll.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider for an DT scroll gresture followed by a left off event to be considered as valid insertial scroll.

Selects inertial scroll delay rate: Low 	- Uses 32-byte array for inertial scroll implementation, reports few intertial scrolls. High - Uses 64-byte array for inertial scroll implementation and reports more intertial scrolls.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on X-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans for ST flick to be valid.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on Y-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans for ST flick to be valid.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected onslider between two concecutive scans for ST flick to be valid.
This parameter defines the maximum time interval for which the component will search for a flick gesture.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on X-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans for DT flick to be valid.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on Y-axis of touchpad between two concecutive scans for DT flick to be valid.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider between two concecutive scans for DT flick to be valid.
This parameter defines the maximum time interval for which the component will search for a flick gesture.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected near the edge (after a touch) for a ST edge swipe to be valid.
The finger position displacement should exceed (Posiiton Threshold) within the time defined by this parameter for a ST edge swipe to be valid.
This parameter defines the time interval for which all other gesture will be ignored after completion of a ST edge swipe gesture.
This parameter defines the maximum angle (in degrees) that the path of finger touch can subtent on the point of touch-down, near the edge.
This parameter defines the maximum angle (in degrees) that the path of finger touch can subtent on the point of touch-down, near the edge.
This parameter defines the edge area. A swipe must start within the this regison to be considered as valid ST edge swipe.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected near the edge (after a touch) for a DT edge swipe to be valid.
The finger position displacement should exceed (Posiiton Threshold) within the time defined by this parameter for a DT edge swipe to be valid.
This parameter defines the time interval for which all other gesture will be ignored after completion of a DT edge swipe gesture.
This parameter defines the maximum angle (in degrees) that the path of finger touch can subtent on the point of touch-down, near the edge.
This parameter defines the maximum angle (in degrees) that the path of finger touch can subtent on the point of touch-down, near the edge.
This parameter defines the edge area. A swipe must start within the this regison to be considered as valid DT edge swipe.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on X-axis of tuchpad between two concecutive scans for DT Zoom to be valid.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on Y-axis of tuchpad between two concecutive scans for DT Zoom to be valid.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on slider between two concecutive scans for DT Zoom to be valid.
This parameter defines number of sequential zoom gestures in perticular direction (in or out) that needs to be detected before a zoom gesture is deemed valid.

If a scroll was detected and zoom is detected without a lift off event (i.e. without removing the fingers from the touchpad), first few zoom gestures specified by this parameter shall be ignoed before reporting a valid zoom gesture.

This parameter sets the number of sequential pan gestures in a particular direction that have to be observed before the rotate gesture is deemed invalid. For example, if this parameter is set to 20 and you are performing a rotate action, then the touch cannot continue in the same direction for 20 pan counts and still have a valid rotate gesture. After this threshold is reached, the reported gesture ceases to be a rotate and the corresponding pan gesture is reported.
If you set this parameter to 0, then you will not have this debounce procedure at all. A rotate gesture will be considered valid and no pan gestures will be detected until a rotate condition will be broken.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on a radial slider between two concecutive scans for ST rotate to be valid.

This parameter sets the number of sequential pan gestures in a particular direction that have to be observed before the rotate gesture is deemed invalid. For example, if this parameter is set to 20 and you are performing a rotate action, then the touch cannot continue in the same direction for 20 pan counts and still have a valid rotate gesture. After this threshold is reached, the reported gesture ceases to be a rotate and the corresponding pan gesture is reported.
If you set this parameter to 0, then you will not have this debounce procedure at all. A rotate gesture will be considered valid and no pan gestures will be detected until a rotate condition will be broken.
This parameter defines the minimum displacement needs to be detected on a radial slider between two concecutive scans for DT rotate to be valid.
HELP
Opens (load) a previously saved configuration (XML) file for CapSense component.
Saves the current component configuration into a (XML) file.

The CapSense component firmware library uses the data structure (known as Register map)
to store the configurable parameters, various outputs and signals of the component.
The Export Register Map button creates an explanation for registers and bit fields in the register map
in PDF or XML file which can be used as reference for development.
Exports the current component register map to the XML format.
Exports the current component register map to the PDF format.
Moves the selected widget up by one on the list.
Moves the selected widget down by one on the list.
Deletes the selected widget from the list.

Shows an icon to indicate the widget type.
Not configurable (i.e. widget type cannot be changed once selected initially).

The editable field to enter a widget name.
The max of 16 aplha-numeric characters only, the first character should be a letter.
Widget names must be unique (case-insensitive).

The drop-down to select the sensing mode for each widget:
the CSD sensing method (Capacitive Sigma Delta) is Cypress patented method of performing self-capacitance measurements.
All widget types support the CSD sensing.
The CSX sensing method is Cypress patented method of performing mutual-capacitance measurements.
Only buttons, matrix buttons, and touchpad widgets support the CSX sensing.

The sensing element refers to terminals of the component assigned to port pins to connect to physical sensors on the user interface panel.
The following element numbers are supported by the CSD sensing method:
Button supports 1 to 32 sensors within a widget.
Linear Slider supports 3 to 32 segments within a widget.
Radial Slider supports 3 to 32 segments within a widget.
Matrix Buttons support 2 to 16 rows and columns. The total intersections number (sensors) are equal to rows X columns, limited to maximum of 32.
Touchpad supports 3 to 16 rows and columns
Proximity supports 1 to 16 sensors within a widget.
The following element numbers are supported by the CSX sensing method:
Button - 1 to 32 Rx electrodes (for 1 to 32 sensors) and Tx is fixed to 1.
Matrix Buttons - 2 to 16 Tx and Rx. The total intersections number (node) is equal to Tx X Rx, limited to maximum of 32.
Indicates the total number of electrodes (port pins) used by the CSD widgets, including Cmod, Csh and Shield electrodes.
Indicates the total number of electrodes (port pins) used by the CSX widgets, including the CintA and CintB capacitors.

Indicates the total number of port pins required for the design. This does not include port pins used by other components in the project. The number of pins required should always be less than or equal to the number of pins available for the project to build it successfully.
Indicates the total number of port pins available for the selected device.
Displays the closest valid value of the modulator clock frequency based on the calculated modulator clock divider (HFCLK/MODCLK ratio).
Displays the closest valid value of the modulator clock frequency based on the calculated modulator clock divider (HFCLK/MODCLK ratio).

Structure with all Ganged Flash electrode objects

Points to the array of the FLASH Sensor Objects or FLASH IO Objects that belong to this widget.
Sensing block uses this pointer to access and configure IOs for the scanning.
Bit #2 in WD_STATIC_CONFIG field indicates the type of array:

0 - IO Object.

Points to the Widget Object in RAM. Sensing block uses it to access scan parameters.
Processing uses it to access threshold and widget specific data.

Points to the array of Sensor Objects in RAM.
The sensing and processing blocks use it to access the scan data.
Points to the array of the Filter History Objects in RAM that belongs to this widget.

Points to the array of the debounce counters.
The size of the debounce counter is 8 bits.
These arrays are not part of the data structure.
